quiz.title: Unit 6: Market Structures (Quiz 5)
quiz.subtitle: 6.5 Long Run Equilibrium in Perfect Competition: Zero Economic Profit Outcome (20 Questions)
quiz.subject: Economics
quiz.topic: Long-run Adjustment, Zero Economic Profit, Productive and Allocative Efficiency

questions.question: In long-run competitive equilibrium, perfectly competitive firms earn:
questions.explanation: Free entry and exit ensure that in long-run equilibrium, firms earn zero economic profit (normal profit only), where they cover all costs including opportunity costs.

questions.question: The long-run equilibrium condition for a perfectly competitive firm is:
questions.explanation: In long-run equilibrium: $P = MC$ (profit maximization) and $P = ATC$ (zero economic profit), so $P = MC = ATC$ at the minimum point of ATC.

questions.question: If firms in a perfectly competitive industry are earning economic profits, in the long run:
options: New firms will enter the industry
questions.explanation: Economic profits attract new firms to enter, increasing market supply and driving down the market price until economic profits are eliminated.

questions.question: If firms in a perfectly competitive industry are incurring economic losses, in the long run:
options: Some firms will exit the industry
questions.explanation: Economic losses cause some firms to exit, reducing market supply and driving up the market price until losses are eliminated and remaining firms earn normal profit.

questions.question: In long-run competitive equilibrium, firms produce at:
options: The point where MC is minimized
The minimum point of the ATC curve
The point where AVC is minimized
The output where MR is maximized
questions.explanation: Competitive pressure forces firms to produce at the minimum point of their average total cost curve, achieving productive efficiency.

questions.question: Allocative efficiency is achieved in perfect competition because:
questions.explanation: Allocative efficiency means resources are allocated to produce the goods and services most valued by society. This occurs when $P = MC$, the value to consumers equals the cost of production.

questions.question: Productive efficiency is achieved in perfect competition because:
options: Goods are produced at minimum cost
The right mix of goods is produced
questions.explanation: Productive efficiency occurs when goods are produced at the lowest possible cost, which happens in long-run competitive equilibrium where firms produce at the minimum ATC.

questions.question: The long-run supply curve for a constant-cost industry is:
questions.explanation: In a constant-cost industry, expansion doesn't affect input prices, so firms' cost curves remain unchanged, and the long-run supply curve is horizontal at $P = min(ATC)$.

questions.question: In an increasing-cost industry, the long-run supply curve is:
questions.explanation: In increasing-cost industries, expansion drives up input prices, raising firms' cost curves, so higher prices are needed to induce more output in the long run.

questions.question: When a perfectly competitive industry reaches long-run equilibrium:
options: No firms want to enter or exit
questions.explanation: With zero economic profit, there's no incentive for new firms to enter or existing firms to exit - the industry is in stable equilibrium.

questions.question: The long-run adjustment process ensures that market price always returns to:
questions.explanation: Entry and exit forces drive price to the minimum ATC in the long run, where firms earn zero economic profit.

questions.question: If technological improvement reduces production costs for all firms, in the long run:
options: Firms will earn permanent economic profits
Market price will decrease to the new minimum ATC
questions.explanation: Cost reductions create temporary economic profits, attracting entry until market price falls to the new, lower minimum ATC.

questions.question: In long-run competitive equilibrium, consumer surplus is:
questions.explanation: Perfect competition maximizes total economic surplus, and with $P = MC$, consumer surplus is maximized given the cost structure.

questions.question: The 'invisible hand' of perfect competition works through:
questions.explanation: The self-correcting mechanism of entry and exit automatically moves the market toward efficient long-run equilibrium without central direction.

questions.question: If market demand increases permanently in a constant-cost industry, the long-run effect is:
questions.explanation: In constant-cost industries, long-run supply is perfectly elastic, so increased demand leads to more firms entering but price returns to original minimum ATC.

questions.question: Normal profit represents:
options: The minimum return needed to keep resources in their current use
questions.explanation: Normal profit is the return just sufficient to keep resources employed in their current use, covering all opportunity costs.

questions.question: In long-run equilibrium, a perfectly competitive firm operates with:
questions.explanation: Firms produce at the minimum of their long-run average cost curve, meaning they've chosen the optimal plant size for their output level.

questions.question: The long-run supply curve is typically more elastic than the short-run supply curve because:
options: Firms can enter or exit the industry
Prices are fixed in the long run
Demand is more elastic in the long run
questions.explanation: In the long run, firms can enter or exit and adjust all inputs, making quantity supplied more responsive to price changes.

questions.question: If a perfectly competitive firm is earning zero economic profit, it:
options: Is covering all explicit costs only
questions.explanation: Zero economic profit means the firm is earning exactly normal profit - enough to cover all costs including the opportunity cost of resources.

questions.question: The key difference between short-run and long-run in perfect competition is:
options: The ability of firms to enter or exit
The shape of the demand curve
questions.explanation: In the short run, the number of firms is fixed. In the long run, firms can enter or exit, which is the mechanism that drives economic profit to zero.

scoreMessages.90: Excellent! You thoroughly understand long-run equilibrium, the adjustment process, and efficiency properties of perfect competition.
scoreMessages.70: Good work! You understand the basic concepts but review the entry/exit mechanism, different cost industries, and efficiency conditions.
scoreMessages.50: A fair start. Focus on: why economic profit is zero in long-run equilibrium, how entry/exit affects price, and the efficiency properties.
scoreMessages.0: Keep practicing! Remember that free entry and exit drive economic profit to zero in the long run, leading to productive and allocative efficiency.
